Pseudo Elements

A CSS selectable part of an element.

  • what are they?
  • a css selectable PART of an element

Pseudo Elements

  • ::after (:after)
  • ::-ms-fill
  • ::-ms-fill-lower
  • ::-ms-fill-upper
  • ::-ms-thumb
  • ::-ms-track
  • ::-moz-progress-bar
  • ::-moz-range-progress
  • ::-moz-range-thumb
  • ::-moz-range-track
  • ::-webkit-progress-bar
  • ::-webkit-progress-value
  • ::-webkit-slider-runnable-track
  • ::-webkit-slider-thumb
  • ::before (:before)
  • ::first-letter (:first-letter)
  • ::first-line (:first-line)
  • ::selection
  • ::backdrop
  • 6 that aren't browser-specific or experimental
  • only 4 that have decent support
  • only 2 that really matter

Pseudo Elements

Positions

element

element

element

element

element

  • standard position
  • absolute position
  • absolute to mimic an :after
  • z-index that mo-fo (-1)
  • just about anything you can do to a normal element, you can do to a pseudo element

Pseudo Elements

Lets Talk About Content

All :before and :after pseudo elements MUST have 'content'.

content: '';
content: '\2605';

content: attr(data-content);
  1. item 1
  2. item 2
  3. item 3
ol {
  counter-reset: my-counter;
  list-style: none;
}
ol li:before {
  content: counter(my-counter);
  counter-increment: my-counter;
}
  • no content and build a shape
  • unicode or icon font character
  • data-
  • custom list items

Pseudo Classes

A CSS selectable state of an element.

  • what are they?
  • a css selectable STATE of an element
  • we should all be familiar with some of these

:hover

if you have never used hover... get out.

Pseudo Classes

Some You Probably Know

:active

:first-child

:focus

:hover

:last-child

:nth-child()

Pseudo Classes

Some You Might Not Know

:checked

:first-of-type

:invalid

:last-of-type

:nth-of-type()

:required

:valid

  • some of these are going to be very integral in the creation of our JS free interactions

Pseudo Classes

All The Classes!!!

:active:any:checked:default:dir():disabled:empty:enabled:first:first-child:first-of-type:fullscreen:focus:hover:indeterminate:in-range:invalid:lang():last-child:last-of-type:left:link:not():nth-child():nth-last-child():nth-last-of-type():nth-of-type():only-child:only-of-type:optional:out-of-range:read-only:read-write:required:right:root:scope:target:valid:visited
  • In the description of this session, i promised to show you how to get great page interactions without js. these little guys are what make that possible. mostly through a little thing known as The Checkbox Hack

The "Checkbox Hack"

Nesting styles after a :checked pseudo class on a checkbox to gain functionality instead of just style

  • often used in combination with animations/transitions
  • built a nice basic one to show you how it works

The "Checkbox Hack"

A Basic Example

markup
CSS
#agree:checked ~ .sign-up-button {
  opacity: 1;
  pointer-events: all;
}
  
#agree ~ .sign-up-button {
  opacity: .6;
  pointer-events: none;
}

( https://css-tricks.com/child-and-sibling-selectors/ )

  • actually show the checkbox
  • common practice is to nest input in label - that won't work here
  • everything that changes based on :checked must be easily decended from the checkbox
  • lets look something more complex

The "Checkbox Hack"

A Checkbox Powered Modal

demo
  • label/id relationship allows multiple labels
  • point out what items are labels
  • 36 lines of CSS (prefixed, and cleanly organized)
  • 40 lines of easy to read SCSS
  • vs 338 for bootstrap modal.js (PLUS jQuery)

The "Checkbox Hack"

.c-tabs #tab-1:checked {
    ~ .c-tabs__nav > label[for='tab-1'] {
      // active tab styles
    }
    
    ~ .c-tabs__content > [data-for='tab-1'] {
      display: block;
    }
  }
  
  &__content-item {
    display: none;
  }
  
  // rest of appearance styles
}
  • radio inputs will only let one be checked at a time
  • reveal.js and/or jade are blocking the checked attribute because of the sample code???

The "(Insert Input/Psuedo Class Here) Hack"

Dropdown Menu

  • just for show to help give creative starting points

The "(Insert Input/Psuedo Class Here) Hack"

Multiple Modals

demo
  • modals that use radio inputs
  • all 'close' triggers point to a 'close' radio button
  • this ensures you can't accidently have multiple modals open

The "(Insert Input/Psuedo Class Here) Hack"

Form Labels

Stacked Label/Input
Inline Label/Input
Placeholder as Label
  • gets monotonous
  • 2 generally accepted options: stacked or inline
    • stacked= + on mobile, - on desktop
    • inline= + on desktop, - on mobile
  • placeholder solution
    • bad - no longer know what the input is for

The "(Insert Input/Psuedo Class Here) Hack"

Form Labels cont.

First Name 

.c-form-group--inset { position: relative; }

.c-form-group--inset .c-input:focus + .c-label--inset,
.c-form-group--inset .c-input:valid + .c-label--inset {
  font-size: .75em;
  opacity: .7;
  top: 0;
}

.c-form-group--inset .c-label--inset {
  left: 10px;
  opacity: 1;
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
}
  • note that the input is required
    • can anybody tell me why we need that? (hint: it isn't for validation)
    • this allows us to use :valid so the labels stays transformed
    • that does it for the actual functionality, but there are more things go into them to make them FEEL right.

Transitions

A change in property values over a specified duration of time instead of occurring immediately

  • what are they?
  • for example, that definition had a transition on it to make the opacity fade from 0 to 1

Transitions

Why bother?

  • they just make things FEEL nicer
  • for example, when these slides change they are using transitions

Transitions

Syntax

.defaults {
  transition-property: all;
  transition-duration: 0s;
  transition-timing-function: ease;
  transition-delay: 0s;
}
.shorthand {
  transition: all 0s ease 0s;
}
  • default properites
  • shorthand

Transitions

Specifying What Changes

button:hover {
  background: #ff6347;
  border-color: #fff;
  box-shadow: 0 0 20px 10px #333;
}

button:hover {
  transition: box-shadow 1s linear;
}
button:hover {
  transition: 
    background 1s linear,
    box-shadow 1s linear;
}
button:hover {
  transition: all 1s linear;
}
  • safe thought: if it can be defined numerically
  • all transition examples will be using buttons, :hover, '1s', and 'linear'
  • notice that each thing transitions evenly from the original to the hover state as well as from the hover state back to the original. we can change that too.

Transitions

Different Reverse Transitions

button {
  transition: box-shadow 1s linear;

  &:hover {
    transition: all 1s linear;
  }
}
  • all the things on hover
  • ONLY box-shadow on return

Transitions

Timing Functions

How to handle the progress of the transition over time

ease
ease-in
ease-out
ease-in-out
linear
steps()
cubic-bezier()
ease
ease-in
ease-out
ease-in-out
linear
steps()
cubic-bezier()
  • there a few keyword functions
  • cubic-bezier can be tricky to master, but gives you a lot more control over how your transitions progress
  • lets see all of them at the same time but way slower

Animations

A change in property values over a specified duration of time instead of occurring immediately

  • notice that is the same definition i gave for transitions

Animations

How are they different?

AnimationsvsTransitions

can stack on top of each other
you only get one per element

can loop
only forward/backward

reset when finished (default)
don't reset when finished

don't reverse themselves
automatically reverse

  • animations stack
  • repeatable
  • reset by default
  • don't automatically reverse

Animations

Syntax

.defaults {
  animation-name: none;
  animation-duration: 0s;
  animation-timing-function: ease;
  animation-delay: 0s;
  animation-iteration-count: 1;
  animation-direction: normal;
  animation-fill-mode: none;
  animation-play-state: running;
}
.shorthand {
  animation: none 0s ease 0s 1 normal none running;
}
  • default properites
  • shorthand
  • name refers to keyframe
  • without keyframe, you have no animation

Animations

Keyframes

.example {
  animation: spin 2s linear infinite;
}@keyframes spin {
  0% {
    transform: rotate(0);
  }
  100% {
    transform: rotate(360deg);
  }
}
  • great resource - animate.css

Animations

What Can We Animate?

-moz-outline-radius-moz-outline-radius-bottomleft-moz-outline-radius-bottomright-moz-outline-radius-topleft-moz-outline-radius-topright-webkit-text-fill-color-webkit-text-stroke-webkit-text-stroke-color-webkit-touch-calloutallbackdrop-filterbackgroundbackground-colorbackground-positionbackground-sizeborderborder-bottomborder-bottom-colorborder-bottom-left-radiusborder-bottom-right-radiusborder-bottom-widthborder-colorborder-leftborder-left-colorborder-left-widthborder-radiusborder-rightborder-right-colorborder-right-widthborder-topborder-top-colorborder-top-left-radiusborder-top-right-radiusborder-top-widthborder-widthbottombox-shadowclipclip-pathcolorcolumn-countcolumn-gapcolumn-rulecolumn-rule-colorcolumn-rule-widthcolumn-widthcolumnsfilterflexflex-basisflex-growflex-shrinkfontfont-sizefont-size-adjustfont-stretchfont-weightgrid-column-gapgrid-gapgrid-row-gapheightleftletter-spacingline-heightmarginmargin-bottommargin-leftmargin-rightmargin-topmaskmask-positionmask-sizemax-heightmax-widthmin-heightmin-widthmotion-offsetmotion-rotationobject-positionopacityorderoutlineoutline-coloroutline-offsetoutline-widthpaddingpadding-bottompadding-leftpadding-rightpadding-topperspectiveperspective-originrightscroll-snap-coordinatescroll-snap-destinationshape-image-thresholdshape-marginshape-outsidetext-decorationtext-decoration-colortext-emphasistext-emphasis-colortext-indenttext-shadowtoptransformtransform-originvertical-alignvisibilitywidthword-spacingz-index
  • these are the properties that are animatable
  • in this case 'can be changed with an animation'
  • not necessarily changed SMOOTHLY
  • rule of thumb = numeric values
  • exception - z-index - paper analogy

Animations

Stacking Animations

.a-bounce {
  animation:
    bounce
    1s
    ease-out
    infinite
    alternate
  ;
}
.a-squish {
  animation:
    squish
    1s
    ease-out
    infinite
    alternate
  ;
}
.a-bounce.a-squish {
  animation-name:
    bounce,
    squish
  ;
}

Animations

Delayed Progress

no delay
positive delay
negative delay
  • 3 elements: no delay, 1s delay, -1s delay
  • which is going to get here first?

Animations

Change The Starting Point

no delay

+ delay

- delay

no delay

+ delay

- delay

no delay

+ delay

- delay

Animations

Chaining Timing Functions

@keyframes sample {
  0% {
    animation-timing-function: ease-in;
    ...
  }
  33% {
    animation-timing-function: steps(5);
    ...
  }
  66% {
    animation-timing-function: ease-out;
    ...
  }
  100% {
    ...
  }
}

  • first up, overlooked animatable elements

Animation Demos

Often Overlooked Options
  • animations (and pseudo elements) can be applied to almost any target
  • including the tag
  • which means we can build simple full page animated backgrounds
  • or rediculously tedious ones
  • combine this with some CSS filters and you can do some really cool things

Animation Demos

Making an Entrance

  • some entrance animation examples
  • these can happen at page load or
  • they make really nice enhancements to ajax loaded data
  • but we aren't talking about that because its js and for the purpose of this session, we don't like js

Box-Shadows

The Basics

button {
  box-shadow: none                  ;
}
button {
  box-shadow: x-offset              ;
}
button {
  box-shadow:          y-offset     ;
}
button {
  box-shadow:                   blur;
}
button {
  box-shadow: 10px 10px 20px;
}

Box-Shadows

The Basics

button {
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px;
}
button {
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px;
}
button {
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px #333;
}
  • Why can't we see the shadow? (give something away)
  • by default - inhert color of text
  • but we can define it
  • now lets look at a functional use case

Box-Shadows

Functional, Not Just Design

  • Information
  • More Information
  • A thing you should know.
  • A much more intensive version of some things that might interest you. At least a little bit, we hope.
  • Something dumb to take up space.
  • Information
  • More Information
  • A thing you should know.
  • A much more intensive version of some things that might interest you. At least a little bit, we hope.
  • Something dumb to take up space.
  • Information
  • More Information
  • A thing you should know.
  • A much more intensive version of some things that might interest you. At least a little bit, we hope.
  • Something dumb to take up space.
    • li {
  box-shadow: 0 1px 0 0 white;
}
  • co-worker had a list - didn't work right on one phone
  • couldn't be fixed with margins or paddings or positions
  • the solution: put a box-shadow on the bottom
  • no affect on dimensions, layout means it will always go behind the next item (in this case)
  • but this is just telling you about box-shadows...

So why are box-shadows so great?

  • so far this is very basic
  • "how is THIS his favorite thing in CSS?"
  • 3 more things i haven't shown you yet
  • each one makes box-shadow exponentially more awesome

The Fantastic 4th Number

Box-Shadows

The 4th Number

box-shadow: 0 0 0 6px #ffa500;
box-shadow: 0 0 0 -6px #ffa500;
box-shadow: 0 20px 0 6px #ffa500;
box-shadow: 0 20px 0 -6px #ffa500;
box-shadow: 0 10px 20px -5px #333;
  • if you've used a box shadow, you problaby know about this already
  • "spread radius"
  • how far the shadow stretches beyond the edge

Its The Final Property

Box-Shadows

The Final Property

box-shadow: inset 0 0 10px 0 #1e90ff;
box-shadow: 0 0 10px 0 #1e90ff inset;

Multiple Shadows

Box-Shadows

Multiple Shadows

box-shadow:
  0 0 0  5px #ff6347,
  0 0 0 10px #ffa500,
  0 0 0 15px #ffd700,
  0 0 0 20px #32cd32,
  0 0 0 25px #1e90ff,
  0 0 0 30px #9370db
;
  • point out list syntax
  • rainbow/double Rainbow
  • now lets look at some more practical uses for this

Box-Shadows

Multiple Shadows

animated underlines

left to right
right to left
expand from center
  • better 3d and glow
  • interesting hover options
  • creative underlining
